awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dispersal Limitation as a Primary Factor in Determining Ectomycorrhizal Community Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Title: Collaborative Research: Dispersal Limitation as a Primary Factor in 	 
Determining Ectomycorrhizal Community Structure 	 
Institution: University of California-Berkeley 	 
Abstract Date: 12/04/07 	 
Ectomycorrhizal fungi are obligate mutualists with temperate forest trees such as pines, 	 
oaks, aspens, and birch. These fungi provide mineral nutrients to the trees in exchange 	 
for sugars, and trees require them for growth and survival. Following severe 	 
disturbance such as forest fires or logging, trees need to reestablish their relationships 	 
with mycorrhizal fungi in order to survive. Prior work has shown that these fungi arrive 	 
in an ordered sequence, or "succession", after such disturbances. A new model is 	 
proposed to explain this observed pattern through differences in spore dispersal and 	 
competitive interactions among mycorrhizal fungi. Four key predictions of this model 	 
concerning limitations to aerial spore dispersal and effect of tree root density on fungal 	 
competition will be tested through a combination of field sampling and manipulative 	 
growth-chamber experiments. The broader impacts of this work are that it will help us 	 
understand an essential biotic process necessary for tree establishment, and will build a 	 
foundation of basic ecological knowledge for an important group of understudied 	 
organisms. Training of graduate and undergraduate students will be an important 	 
component of this research. In addition this work takes advantage of its location within 	 
Point Reyes National Seashore by feeding back into management decisions within the 	 
park and through outreach efforts directed towards public education.

por.por_cntn:
This award examined how communities of ectomycorrhizal fungi change over time.  We found that the changes in community structure and diversity can be linked to both environmental conditions and interactions amongst the fungi themselves.  It apears that following disturbance, certain fungi are well adpated to living in environments with low root density and limited competition.  As the forests begin to recover, however, those early species are replaced species that are more successful colonizers in areas of high root density and stronger competition.  Our results indicate that, similar to larger organisms such as plants, there appears to be a tradeoff between competition and colonization among ectomycorrhizal fungi.  Future reseach further examining this trade-off in other systems will be important for better understanding the dynamics of belowground fungal communities as well as how forests to respond to disturbance.  The research conducted in this award involved a large number of undergraduate students.  Many have gone onto successful graduate school careers in science.  In addition, the award involved collaboration with high school teachers to develop ways of exposing K-12 students to microbial ecology.  Presentations of the research have been given in multiple venues including professional and amateur societal meetings as well as 10 publications in peer-reviewed journals.


Last Modified: 05/02/2012
Modified by: Peter Kennedy

This award examined how communities of ectomycorrhizal fungi change over time.  We found that the changes in community structure and diversity can be linked to both environmental conditions and interactions amongst the fungi themselves.  It apears that following disturbance, certain fungi are well adpated to living in environments with low root density and limited competition.  As the forests begin to recover, however, those early species are replaced species that are more successful colonizers in areas of high root density and stronger competition.  Our results indicate that, similar to larger organisms such as plants, there appears to be a tradeoff between competition and colonization among ectomycorrhizal fungi.  Future reseach further examining this trade-off in other systems will be important for better understanding the dynamics of belowground fungal communities as well as how forests to respond to disturbance.  The research conducted in this award involved a large number of undergraduate students.  Many have gone onto successful graduate school careers in science.  In addition, the award involved collaboration with high school teachers to develop ways of exposing K-12 students to microbial ecology.  Presentations of the research have been given in multiple venues including professional and amateur societal meetings as well as 10 publications in peer-reviewed journals.
